content.text: A set of beliefs is **inconsistent** if they can't all be true together. Inconsistency is a serious problem in reasoning - if your beliefs contradict, at least one must be false.

content.definition: A set of statements is inconsistent if it's impossible for all of them to be true at the same time. Accepting all of them leads to a contradiction.

content.title: An Inconsistent Set
content.conclusion: These three statements cannot all be true together.
content.note: If the first two are true, the third must be false. This is a logical inconsistency.

content.definition: A statement that undermines itself or makes itself false. The very act of stating it creates a contradiction.

content.title: Self-Defeating Statements
premises: "I know that no one can know anything."
content.conclusion: Each statement contradicts itself when you apply it to itself.
content.note: These are self-referentially inconsistent - they refute their own claims.

symbols.name: Hidden Contradiction
symbols.example: "All ravens are black" and "My raven is white"

symbols.name: Statement Undermines Itself
symbols.meaning: Applying statement to itself yields contradiction

content.text: When you discover inconsistency in your beliefs, you must revise. But which belief should you change? Usually, give up the one that's least well-supported by evidence or least central to your other beliefs.

content.question: "All generalizations are false." What's wrong with this statement?
options: It's too vague to be meaningful
It's self-defeating - it's itself a generalization
It commits the ad hominem fallacy
content.explanation: The statement 'All generalizations are false' is itself a generalization. If it's true, then it's false (because it's a generalization that would have to be false). This makes it self-defeating - it refutes itself.
